In the worst shooting 
      in U.S. 
      history, we know 33 people, including the shooter, are dead. But we don't 
      really know exactly why Cho Seung-Hui went on a rampage on the campus of 
      Virginia Tech. For our first story, correspondent Scott Pelley talks 
      to Secret Service intelligence officers, whose exhaustive research into 
      the minds of potential assassins and school shooters will provide valuable 
      insights. Pelley is speaking with the officers today, April 20, and 
      will report this story over the weekend, for what will perhaps be the 
      freshest look yet at the mind of this mass killer.

 
 
This past week was also the 
      deadliest in Baghdad – over 200 Iraqis were killed in 
      a single day.  It has become a living hell for citizens of Baghdad just trying 
      to get through an average day, as correspondent Lara Logan reports 
      in our second story. How does one live in such a place?  Very 
      carefully, reports Logan, and often with 
      the protection of a weapon, or in the case of Dr. Quoresh al-Kasir, the 
      U.S. military. Nearly 200 
      doctors have been murdered in Iraq by insurgents intent on 
      destroying Iraqi society. Soon after bullets began to crash through 
      his windows, Dr. Quoresh heard a hopeful sound. "We heard the 
      helicopters starting to come to the area. My sons and daughter said, 'Oh, 
      Baba, the Americans started to reach the area.'"
 
Watch Logan's Reporter's 
      Notebook.
 
 
The firing of Don Imus for 
      uttering racially charged and misogynistic words black rap stars routinely 
      use in their lyrics has shifted the spotlight to hip-hop culture and its 
      dark messages.  As you’ll see in our third piece, CNN's Anderson Cooper discovers that 
      one of the rappers’ popular messages, "stop snitchin'," does not help the 
      police, but has actually confounded investigators' efforts to solve 
      crimes, especially murder, and has now created some lawless 
      neighborhoods.  Says Geoffrey Canada, educator and anti-violence 
      advocate from New York City’s Harlem neighborhood, "It’s like we’re saying to the 
      criminals, 'You can have our community….Do anything you want and we will 
      either deal with it ourselves or we’ll simply ignore 
      it.'"
 
Watch Cooper's Reporter's 
      Notebook.
 
 
These stories, and Andy Rooney's love affair with 
      books, this Sunday, April 22, on 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. 
      ET/PT.
